Can arm me with, expect to meet his faith
As noble as he promis'd---Ha! it is he.
My poor heart trembles like a timorous leaf,
Which the wind shakes upon his sickly stalk,
And frights into a Palsy.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Felisarda!

sp.speaker: Felis.
sp.l: Shall I want fortitude to bid him welcome?
Sir, if you think there is a heart alive
That can be grateful, and with humble thoughts,
And Prayers reward your piety, despise not
The offer of it here; you have not cast
Your bounty on a Rock, while the seeds thrive
Where you did place your Charity; my joy
May seem ill dressed to come like sorrow thus,
But you may see through every tear, and find
My eyes meant Innocence, and your hearty welcome.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Who did prepare thee Felisarda thus
To entertain me weeping? sure our souls
Meet and converse, and we not know it; there is
Such beauty in that watery circle, I
Am fearful to come near, and breath a kiss
Upon thy cheek, lest I pollute that Crystal,
And yet I must salute thee, and I dare
With one warm sigh meet, and dry up this sorrow.

sp.speaker: Felis.
sp.l: I shall forget all misery; for when
I look upon the World, and race of men,
I find them proud, and all so unacquainted
With pity to such miserable things
As poverty hath made us, that I must
Conclude you sent from Heaven.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: O do not Flatter
Thyself poor Felisarda; I am Mortal,
The life I bear about me is not mine,
But borrowed to come to thee once again,
And ere I go, to clear how much I love thee---
But first I have a story to deliver,
A tale will make thee sad, but I must tell it,
There is one dead that loved thee not.

sp.speaker: Felis.
sp.l: One dead
That loved not me? this carries sir in nature
No killing sound; I shall be sad to know
I did deserve an Enemy, or he want
A Charity at death.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Thy cruel Enemy,
And my best friend, hath took Eternall leave
And is gone, to heaven I hope, excuse my tears,
It is a tribute I must pay his memory,
For I did love my Father.

sp.speaker: Felis.
sp.l: Ha! your Father?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Yes Felisarda, he is gone, that in
The morning promised many years, but death
Hath in few hours made him as stiff, as all
The winds, and winter, had thrown cold upon him,
And whispered him to marble.

sp.speaker: Felis.
sp.l: Now trust me,
My heart weeps for him, but I understand
Not how I was concerned in his displeasure;
And in such height as you profess.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: He did
Command me on his blessing to forsake thee;
Was it not a cruel precept, to enforce
The soul, and curse his Son for honest love?

sp.speaker: Felis.
sp.l: This is a wound indeed.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: But not so mortal;
For his last breath was Balsam poured upon it,
By which he did reverse his malediction;
And I that groaned beneath the weight of that
Anathema, sunk almost to despair,
Where night and heavy shades hung round about me,
Found myself rising like the morning Star
To view the World.

sp.speaker: Felis.
sp.l: Never I hope to be
Eclipsed again.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: This was a welcome blessing.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Heaven had a care of both; my joys are mighty.
Vouchsafe me sir your pardon if I blush
And say I love, but rather than the peace
That should preserve your bosom, suffer for
My sake, it were better I were dead.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: No, live.
And live for ever happy, thou deservedest it.
It is Fernando doth make haste to sleep
In his forgotten dust.

sp.speaker: Felis.
sp.l: Those accents did
Not sound so cheerfully.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: dost love me?

sp.speaker: Felis.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Do not, I prithee do not, I am lost,
Alas I am no more Fernando, there
Is nothing but the Empty name of him
That did betray thee, place a guard about
Thy heart betime, I am not worth this sweetness.

sp.speaker: Felis.
sp.l: Did not Fernando speak all this? alas
He knew that I was poor before, and needed not
Despise me now for that.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Desert me goodness
When I upbraid thy wants. It is I am poor,
For I have not a stock in all the World
Of so much dust, as would contrive one narrow,
Cabin to shroud a worm; my dying Father
Hath given away my Birthright to Francisco,
I am disinherited, thrown out of all,
But the small Earth I borrow, thus to walk on;
And having nothing left, I come to kiss thee,
And take my everlasting leave of thee too.
Farewell, this will persuade thee to consent
To my Eternall absence.

sp.speaker: Felis.
sp.l: I must beseech you stay a little sir,
And clear my faith. Hath your displeased Father
Deprived you then of all, and made Francisco
The Lord of your Inheritance, without hope
To be repaired in Fortune?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: It is sad truth.

sp.speaker: Felis.
sp.l: This is a happiness I did not look for.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: A happiness?

sp.speaker: Felis.
sp.l: Yes Sir, a happiness.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Can Felisarda take delight to hear
What hath undone her servant?

sp.speaker: Felis.
sp.l: Heaven avert it.
But it is not worth my grief to be assured
That this will bring me nearer now to him
Whom I most honour of the World; and it is
My pride, if you exceed me not in Fortune,
That I can boast my heart, as high, and rich,
With noble flame, and every way your equal,
And if you be as poor as I Fernando,
I can deserve you now, and love you more
Than when your expectation carried all
The pride and blossoms of the spring upon it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Those shadows will not feed more than our fancies;
Two poverties will keep but a thin table;
And while we dream of this high nourishment,
We do but starve more gloriously.

sp.speaker: Felis.
sp.l: It is ease.
And wealth first taught us art to surfeit by;
Nature is wise, not costly, and will spread
A table for us in the Wilderness;
And the kind Earth keep us alive, and healthful,
With what her bosom doth invite us to;
The brooks, not there suspected as the Wine
That sometime Princes quaff, are all transparent,
And with their pretty murmurs call to taste them.
In every tree a Chorister to sing
Health to our loves, our lives shall there be free
As the first knowledge was from sin, and all
Our dreams as Innocent.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: O Felisarda?
If thou didst own less Virtue, I might prove
Unkind and marry thee, but being so rich
In goodness, it becomes me not to bring
One that is poor, in every worth, to waste
So excellent a Dower, be free, and meet
One that hath Wealth to cherish it, I shall
Undo thee quite, but pray for me, as I,
That thou mayst change for a more happy Bridegroom;
I dare as soon be guilty of my death,
As make thee miserable by expecting me.
Farewell, and do not wrong my soul, to think
That any storm could separate us two,
But that I have no fortune now to serve thee.

sp.speaker: Felis.
sp.l: This will be no exception sir, I hope,
When we are both dead, yet our bodies may
Be cold, and strangers in the Winding sheet;
We shall be married when our spirits meets.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Your daughter does not use me well Don Carlos .

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I know not what to think,
Some great misfortune must be the cause.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Not yet appear? they might,
And they had crept like Tortoises, Arrived
Before this time.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: There is some strange disaster.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: The Coach overthrown, and both their lives
Endangered, can but excuse them.
O my Lord, Don Carlos .

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: The Tragic voice of women strikes mine ear.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Alsimira?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Where is our Daughter?

sp.speaker: Alsi.
sp.l: My fear almost distracts me, she is gone,
Stolen, ravished from me.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Alsi.
sp.l: An armed Troop
In Vizards forced her from my coach; and heaven
Knows where they have hurried the poor Jacinta .

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: A troop of armed Devils.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Let them be
A legion, they are all damned.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Nay they were men and mortal sure.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I will not leave one soul amongst them all.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Mine is in torment.
In the hope and height of my ambition
To be thus crossed! how scaped you?

sp.speaker: Alsi.
sp.l: Alas I was not young enough, I offered
Myself to bear her company, and suffer
As much as she did, but one boisterous fellow
With a starched voice, and a worse vizard, took me
Just here above my Sciatica, and quoited me
Into the coach again upon my head,
I had a larum in it for half an hour,
And so I scaped with life.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Did they use her with any rigour?

sp.speaker: Alsi.
sp.l: To say truth they were gentle enough to her.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: That mollifies, and they may live.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Hell overtake them, let us return, they had better
Committed incest, than this rape.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: They had better ravished Proserpine before
Don Lucifer's own face. I am all fury.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Pardon my dear Jacinta, It was love
That threw me on this act, I had no patience
To see thee forced into a marriage
By a covetous Father, whose devotion
Is only Wealth and Title; I esteem
No danger, if at last the fair Jacinta
Smile and allow this duty; let not silence
Deprive me longer of thy voice, whose every
Accent will please, though it pronounce my sentence;
There is death in this Eclipse too, sweet dismiss
Thy ungentle veil, and let thy eyes make bright
This melancholy air, that droops and dies
For want of thy restoring beams.

sp.speaker: Est.
sp.l: Now sir,
What think you of your Mistress?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You are the Lady Estefania I take it.

sp.speaker: Est.
sp.l: Yes, you did take me from the coach Alberto
But by a consequence I find, you thought
Jacinta in your power, I could have told you,
Had you discovered sooner what you were,
Where to have found your Mistress, but she is now
Above your hope, and by the priest ere this
Made wife to Don Francisco .

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: To Don Pedro?

sp.speaker: Est.
sp.l: It was not sir impossible that I
(Had not your violence prevented me)
(By a plot between Jacinta and myself,
To take her place and person in the coach)
Had by this time been married to Count Pedro,
Whom I have power and Justice sir to challenge
If Contracts carry weight.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Have I so long
Lain beating at the bush, and is the bird
Fled to Francisco?

sp.speaker: Est.
sp.l: I should show I had
A passion sir, and sense of this captivity,
But that I find it was error, and not will
Lead you to this; and your own loss now made
Irreparable, helps to tie up my anger.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Madam, I must confess a wrong, and dare
Submit to let your anger punish me,
For I despise myself, now I have lost
My expectation, and if you please
To think I had no malice in this act
To you, You can propose no satisfaction
I shall esteem a penance to repair you,
As far as my poor life, if you will direct it.

sp.speaker: Est.
sp.l: It is nobly promised sir. You shall redeem
In my thoughts what is past, if you be pleased
To make my stay no longer here; I have
No desperate aim to make Don Pedro yet
Know how to right me, or make public what
Should bind his honour to perform.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Was not Luys Madam entertained your Servant?

sp.speaker: Est.
sp.l: I shall make known the story if you walk
But to Don Carlos House.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You shall command me.

div1.stage:
Exeunt.
Enter Carlos, Alsimira, and Servant.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No news yet of Jacinta?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: None.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: He must
Not live in Spain, nor in the World, if my
Revenge can overtake him, that has stolen
My Daughter; could you not by voice or habit
Guess at the ravisher? Ye are traitors all.

sp.speaker: Alsi.
sp.l: Now I consider better, I suspect
Alberto one of the conspiracy,
Some voice did sound like his. You know he loved her.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Ha! Alberto?

sp.speaker: Alsi.
sp.l: And how he might engage some Ruffians
To cross Don Pedro .

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: It was he, where is Luys?
I do not like his absence, they are both guilty;
My own blood turned a rebel? send for the Alcaides,
They shall both trot like thieves to the Corregidor.
Where is Count Pedro?

sp.speaker: Alsi.
sp.l: Gon in search of his lost Mistress.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: When all things were ripe,
The very Priest prepared to seal our Joys,
A work my brain did labour for, and sweat
With hope to see accomplished, undermined?
And in a Minute all blown up?

sp.speaker: Alsi.
sp.l: Have patience
She may be found again.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: But how my Lord
May be inclined to accept her foiled, or wounded
In fame---

sp.speaker: Alsi.
sp.l: Luys is here.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Borachio, here is a spectacle! more affliction?
Where is your Sister, what has become of Jacinta?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: My Sister and Jacinta are gone together.
I know all the business.

sp.speaker: Alsi.
sp.l: Where is she?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: She is very well, I know not where she is.
But Don Alberto is an honest Gentleman,
And has by this time done the feat.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Confusion---

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: You think you had all the wit, it was my plot.
You may thank heaven that you are old, and ugly,
You had been no Mother of this World. But sir,
I have some news would be delivered privately.
Mother of mine, avant.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thou art not my Son.
Was ever man so miserable? away
Thou spunge; get him to sleep,

sp.speaker: Alsi.
sp.l: I dare not meddle with him.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: In sobriety a word.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Where is Alberto?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Where every honest man should be a bed, with my Sister,
Old man, I haveconsider'd on the former matter we talked on
And would do things like a dutiful son, but I find that a
Wife is not altogether so convenient for me as a---

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Will none deliver me?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: They are somewhat slug,
Now I have found out an excellent tumbler,
That can do the Somerset, please you to be acquainted with her, and give me your opinion,
She shall play with all the stews in Christendom, for all you are worth, if I live,
and yet she is but seventeen there is a periwinkle, I had a Gemini, before I went to travel,
And I am bound in conscience, if you think fit, to see her well Provided for---

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: With whips, I will have her skin flayed off.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Her skin flayed off? dost thou know mortal man
What thou hast said? I tell the Don, nothing can come near
Her in the shape of an Officer, she is a very Basilisk and will
Kill them with her eyes three score yards point blank, but you
May talk, and do your pleasure with her, for I came a
Purpose to bring her to your lodging, if you love me,
Do but see her, it shall cost you nothing, you shall
Be my friend, hang money?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thus will my state consume, vexation!
What shall I do? when you have slept, Luys
I will tell you more, attend him to his Chamber
And make his Door fast.

sp.speaker: Luys.
sp.l: You will consider on it, upon those terms, I will go
Sleep at winkling.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: And will not all this take away my senses?
My Son is lost too, this is all a curse
For my ambition and my Avarice.

div1.stage: Enter Alsimira and a servant with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: News Don Carlos from our Daughter.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Ha, a Letter! it is Iacintas hand.

sp.speaker: Alsi.
sp.l: Knowest where she is?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Yes Madam, and her resolution
To attend her Father, with my Master Don Francisco
If Don Carlos please to admit them, the matters done.

sp.speaker: Alsi.
sp.l: What matter?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: They are as fast as any Priest can make them.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Wife to Francisco, now his Fathers heir?
That is some allay, if it be true, she writes,
Don Pedro was contracted to Estefania, who supplied
Her person in the Coach---it was not Jacinta was ravished
Then, Don Pedro was not noble, after he had made faith,
To entangle my Iacinta . Hum, say they shall
Be welcome.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: They are present sir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I am nor yet collected, but if this
Paper be justified, I receive you both.
Peruse those wonders Alsimira .

sp.speaker: Iacin.
sp.l: Sir, though by the tie of nature you may challenge
All duty, this is done so like a Father
It exceeds all your care.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Let this confirm,
I bring a fortune not to be despised,
But were I Master of the World, I should
At price of all my wealth, think this a treasure
Purchased too cheap.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: My blessing and my prayers, I am new created,
And bow to that great providence; all Joy
Spread through your souls; this is not much amiss.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: But what is become of Madam Estefania
That took Iacintas place?

sp.speaker: Alsi.
sp.l: Forced from the Coach
By Don Alberto, thinking her my Daughter

sp.speaker: Iacin.
sp.l: That part of our plot failed, but my intents
Were fair, and to assist this injured Lady

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Don Pedro sir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You shall for some few minutes.
Withdraw into that Chamber, in his passion
He may be violent, leave me to moderate.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I shall obey you sir.

sp.speaker: Fed.
sp.l: Was ever man of my great birth and fortune
Affronted thus? I am become the talk
Of every Picaro and Ladron, I challenge
A reparation of my honour; where is
Jacinta? it is a plot, a base contrivement
To make my name ridiculous, the subject
Of every scurril language.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: My Lord with pardon
Of your Altesa, you are not Injured here,
Unless I have been faulty in too much
Observance, and desires to serve your person,
With almost sacrifice of my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Ha! too much to me?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I would you had remembered
How much your Honour was engaged before,
By Contract to another, when you mocked,
The Innocent Jacinta, now not mine.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Who hath traduced my fame, or mentioned me
With that dishonour? I disclaim all Contracts.
The unconfined Air is not more free, than I
To all the World, except your beauteous Daughter.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Do you know the Lady Estefania?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Dares she make saucy claim? my breath dissolves it
If every Lady whom we grace with our
Converse should challenge men of my Nobility---

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I wish my Lord you could evade it, for
The honour of my Family; if your conscience
Or Art can nullify that Lady's interest
I am resolv'd---my Son Luys shall
Then marry With that Widow, I have no other
Ambition.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: You are wise, and I
Am fortified to clear myself thought-free

div1.stage: Enter Alberto, Estefania with a Letter.

sp.l: From any promise to that sullen Madam.
Ha! it is Jacinta, and she wears the Jewel
I did present, conspicuously; I ask
No reason for thy absence, let me chain.
My darling in this amorous curl, it is happiness
Enough to repossess thee, not the policy
And power of Hell shall separate us again.

sp.speaker: Este.
sp.l: It is but Justice sir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Ha! Estefania .

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Do you know her sir?

sp.speaker: Este.
sp.l: Do you know this character?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Conspiracy.

sp.speaker: Est.
sp.l: When this is read Don Carlos
You will imagine he has wronged your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Is this your hand Count Pedro?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Mine---it is counterfeit
Upon my honour, and I thus dissolve
Thy insolent claim.

sp.speaker: Este.
sp.l: Nothing can bind I see
A false heart

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: This must give you freedom Madam,
If you release his hasty vow.

sp.speaker: Este.
sp.l: Faith cannot
Be compelled sir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: These are all Impostures;
I take myself into myself.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What shall become of her my noble Count?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I pity her
But cannot cure her wound, and if you be
Her friend, advise her to contain her passions,
And wisely love one that can entertain it.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: You hear this Madam?

sp.speaker: Este.
sp.l: And can smile upon
His violated faith.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Now for Luys,
To strike in with the Widow.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: He is asleep.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I will wake and quicken him.

sp.speaker: Este.
sp.l: Hadst thou been worth my love, I should have held
Thee worth my anger shadow, of a Lord.
Thy greatness I despise, and think thee now
Too poor for my revenge, and freely give
Thee back thy barren promises, and when
I read in story, one that has been perjured,
I will write Don Pedro in the place of him
That broke his faith, and thank my fate to have missed thee.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: If you please Madam, while he is in the humour
Of being base, I will make him gather up
These paper relics, which he shall make himself
Up into rolls, and having swallowed them
For Pills, thank you, his Physic was so gentle.

sp.speaker: Este.
sp.l: It will be too much time and breath lost on him.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: It will become me Madam to attend you.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: So, she is taken off and my path free
To Carlos Daughter.

sp.speaker: Luys.
sp.l: Contracted to Don Pedro? say.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: She was, where is Estefania?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Gone with Alberto; proud to wait upon
The Lady I neglected.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Follow them Luys?
I do not like he should insinuate
Now she is free, and his hopes desperate in
Jacintas love.

sp.speaker: Luys.
sp.l: How long have I slept sir?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thou dost dream still, pursue the Widow now
Or never look at such a fortune.

sp.speaker: Luys.
sp.l: Is she gone with Alberto? what if I say,
I have lain with her, and that she is with child by me?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: That would stain both your fames; away and welcome
When thou returnest, and she confirmed.

sp.speaker: Luys.
sp.l: I will confirm her, or confound somebody,
No more, I am awake, this is Don Pedro
I will talk with him first, will you justify,
The Widow is a Widow still, and sweet
For all your Contract, that you have not been
My rival as they say after the flesh,
And that you did not know I had a mind,
Or not a mind, to do the deed of Matrimony?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Not I upon my honour.

sp.speaker: Luys.
sp.l: You are witness---now to Alberto .

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Manage the business temperately.

sp.speaker: Luys.
sp.l: Let me alone to be temperate, if I do not cozen
Somebody, let me never drink Sack again.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: What think you of Jacinta now my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: As on the Saint I pay my chief devotions.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I come to seek one, that I late called Brother,
But he hath forfeited that Name, and Justice
Weary of such a prodigy in nature
Hath armed me thus in her revenge, Don Carlos,
Obscure him not, no darkness can protect him,
My sword shall forage every room like lightning,
No Cave but it shall visit, and through ribs
Of steel compel my passage to his heart,
Although I meet him in his Mistress Arms,
The lovers Sanctuary, I dare force Francisco,
And with my Sword cut the Embrace that chains him,
Rather than he shall glory in my ruins,
And revel out, those honours, with her, he
Took from my blood.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: It shall not need Fernando .

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Hum, here is like to be a bloody business,
I will not disturb them.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: As you are Brothers, by your Fathers dust
That should sleep quiet in his Urn, by her
Dear name that gave you life, that now prays for you,
Chide this unnatural fury.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: What demands Fernando?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My inheritance wrought from me
By thy sly creeping to supplant my birth,
And cheat our Fathers easy soul, unworthily
Betraying to his anger for thy lust
Of wealth, the love and promise of two hearts,
Poor Felisarda and Fernando now
Wither at soul, and robbed by thee of that
Should cherish virtue, like to rifled Pilgrims
Met on the way, and having told their story,
And dropped their even tears for both their loss,
Wander from one another.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: It is not sure
Fernando, but his passion (that obeys not
The counsel of his reason) would accuse me,
And if my Father now, since spirits lose not
Intelligence, but more active when they have
Shook off their chains of flesh, would leave his dwelling,
And visit this course orb again: my Innocence
Should dare the appeal, and make Fernando see
His empty accusations.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: He that thrives
By wicked art, has confidence to dress
His action with simplicity, and shapes
To cheat our credulous natures, it is my wonder
Thou durst do so much injury Francisco
As must provoke my Justice, to revenge,
Yet wear no Sword.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I need no guard, I know
Thou darest not kill me.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Dare I not?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: And name thy cause, it is thy suspicion not Francisco
Hath wrought thee high and passionate, to assure it,
If you dare violate, I dare possess you
With all my title to your Land.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: How is that?
Will you resign the interest to such
A fair Estate, and wrong my Daughter sir?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Let him receive it at his peril.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: It was my Fathers act, not mine, he trembled
To hear his curse alive, what horror will
His conscience feel, when he shall spurn his dust,
And call the reverend shade from his blest seat,
To this bad World again, to walk and fright him?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I am abused

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Can this be more than dream?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sir you may cancel it, but think withal
How you can answer him that is dead, when he
Shall charge your timorous soul for this contempt
To nature and Religion, to break
His last bequest, and breath, that sealed your blessings?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: These are fine fancies.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Here, and may it prosper,
Where my good Father meant it, I am overcome.
Forgive me, and enjoy it, I may find
Some Earth that is not thine, where I may die
And take up a dark Chamber, love Jacinta,
And while I seek out where to be forgotten
Live happy, and divide the spring between you,

div1.stage: Enter Ramires, Felisarda, and Teodoro, a loof.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: So, so, all is well again.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: Fernando stay.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ha, my Father and Felisarda?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Don Ramyres and my Niece?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Are they both dead?
I dare kneel too, they do converse. Don Carlos!
Do not you know that shape? it is wondrous like
Your Niece.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: And that your Father, ha!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: How long hath Felisarda been a sad
Companion to the shades? I did not think
To find thee in this pale society,
Of ghosts so soon.

sp.speaker: Felisar.
sp.l: I am alive Fernando,
And Don Ramires still, thy living Father.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You may believe it sir, I was of the counsel.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: It is a joy will tempt me, wish to live
Here, without more ambition to change
For blessings of the other World; and is
My Father willing that we both should live?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Men thought you dead.

sp.speaker: Ramir.
sp.l: It lay within the knowledge of Francisco and some few
By this device to advance my younger Son
To a Marriage with Jacinta sir, and try
Fernando's Piety and his Mistress Vertue,
Which I have found worth him, and my acceptance,
With her I give thee what thy birth did challenge.
Receive thy Felisarda .

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: It is a joy,
So flowing, it drowns all my faculties,
My soul will not contain I fear, but lose
And leave me in this ecstasy.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I am cheated.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Not so, what dower you add above that fortune,
Descends upon her by your Sisters Legacy
Francisco shall deserve, with a proportion
Out of my state; live, and be happy both,
You shall not want a Father in my care.
Our children thus increased Don Carlos, it is
Our shame if we neglect them; Teodoro
You now may call me Brother.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: I am honoured.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Well, take my blessing too, love her Francisco .
My bounty is to come, and if my Son
But finish with his Mistris---he is returned,
Where is the Widow?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Sure enough.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: And Don Alberto .

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I have made him sure too, I have peppered him.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: In your ear, I have cut his throat, do none pursue me?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I hope thou hast not killed him? ha!

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: You hope too late, I could not help it, you said
He was my Rival.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Not too loud.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Where, where shall I obscure me, the Alcaides
Will be here presently, and search for me.
I left him giving up the ghost, at a cranny
I made into his side, through which a man
Might see into his midriff.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Art thou desperate?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Beside one window that did look into his lungs,
From whence his wind came strong enough,
In six hours sail to dispatch a Carrack to the straights.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I am mad.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I should neglect my life, but it would not sound well
With your honour that Don Carlos Son was hanged,
Or put into the Galleys; are they not come yet?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I am undone, there is no safety here,
Make fast those doors, and by the Postern gate
Thou mayst escape, take the best Horse, away.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I shall want money sir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Come follow me?
This accident I fear will quite distract me.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: You must dispatch me quickly sir, there is
No staying to tell the money, give it me in lump,
I will count it afterwards, good sir make haste.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Something hath happened that doth fresh
Perplex him.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Where is Don Pedro?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: He is here.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: The storm is over sure, I hear no noise,
Toledos are asleep, Jacinta? have
I found my love?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Here it was lost indeed,
I must allow no such Familiarity
With my Wife.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: How? married?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: It is most true my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: You have not used me thus?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: It had been Impious to divorce your heart
From Estefania; My good Lord, we know
Your Lordship is religious in your promises.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I defy all Estefanias, Lady you are civil.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: It will become my care so to preserve her
My Honourable Count.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Honourable?
It appears not by these contempts.

sp.speaker: Ramyr.
sp.l: Your Lordship cannot want a Female Furniture.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I must have somebody now I am prepared, my blood
Will take it ill, would I had Estefania;
She is here, Madam I hope you have
A better faith than to believe I was in Earnest,
Don Pedro is only at your service.

sp.speaker: Este.
sp.l: It is too late sir, this Gent. is witness,
Of your surrender, and is now possessed
Of all that is mine.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: It was your Noble bounty,
For which I cannot study a return
More apt than to resign to your good Lordship,
My Interest in Jacinta, give you joy Count.
Such a rich Widow serves my turn.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: So so,
If I consider well this is but Justice.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Ha, are not you Don Alberto: fetch back Luys .

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: The very same sir, and this Lady is my Wife,
Please you salute her.

sp.speaker: Luys.
sp.l: Sir for the credit of your wisdom talk not,
The man you see is alive and married too,
With my consent, alas I owed him money,
That Widow has paid all, I must be honest,
I had no heart to leave you so unsatisfied,
My debts do clog my conscience, and are better
When they are timely paid sir, then let run
With their long Teeth to bite your state hereafter,
And if when I am free you dare but trust me---

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Was ever Father cheated thus, come hither,
How darest thou be so impudent?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I cannot help it sir, unless you dye
Or give me better means, I shall make bold
With these devices, you are my Father sir,
And I am bound---

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: To cozen me?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: All must be mine, and if
I pay myself a little before the day,
You shall be no loser when you come to reckon,
This shall not make a breach betwixt you and I,
They are honest men I owe this money too,
When I am clear prescribe me any method
And rank me like your son, I will deserve
You shall forget my wildness, and acknowledge me
A convert without blemish to your family.

sp.speaker: Rami.
sp.l: I must be Intercessor.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.l: And we all.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I will think upon it.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Since I cannot have Jacinta, I desire
I may have her Brother.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Not in marriage.

sp.speaker: Fed.
sp.l: I like his wit, his spirit, and his humour,
Do not you love a wench?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Thou shalt never want.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Wenches?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: We will live together, and, if thy Father
Be not bountiful, thou shalt command my fortune.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: You speak nobly.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Ladies, I ask your pardon
Unless you hold me desperate, disdain not
That I may this day wait upon your triumph,
And to each Bride offer some gift to expiate
My folly and offence.

sp.speaker: Rami.
sp.l: You are too bountiful.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You are all my guests today.

sp.speaker: Rami.
sp.l: I beg your next
Remove may place the Scene of Joy with me,
My house shall be much honoured, lead the way
With Verse and Wine let Poets crown this day.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: So so, your danger is over, and the state
Secure, as when our Fleet in Eighty Eight
Was fired and scattered, to confirm it true
Here is Don Pedro taken Prisoner too,
I am at your mercy Gentlemen, and I
Confess without a rack conspiracy,
So far as my poor part in the Play comes too,
But I am innocent from hurt to you,
And I dare quit the rest from any plot
Meant but to please, if you believe it not
I dare make oath, your hands can do no less
Than certify your friends what I confess.
